question.title: Version catalogs: Naming/referencing dependencies
question.body:
I try to understand how libraries are named in a toml version-catalog and then referred to, in a gradle-file.

Obviously the last part of the "group" is repeated as the first part of the "name"?

In the gradle-file "Implementation"-section first the "group" is used and then comes the last part of the name, without the redundant part?

[libraries]
androidx-core-ktx = { group = "androidx.core", name = "core-ktx", version.ref = "coreKtx" }
// Results in:
implementation(libs.androidx.core.ktx)


androidx-lifecycle-viewmodel-compose = { module = "androidx.lifecycle:lifecycle-viewmodel-compose", version.ref = "lifecycleRuntimeKtx" }
// Results in:
implementation(libs.androidx.lifecycle.viewmodel.compose)

What't the general convention concerning the naming of "group" and "name", respectively the later usage?

answers.body:
The "group" and "name" are the GA (GroupID, ArtfactID) coordinates of the dependency. The "module" is just the group and name combined into a single value separated by a colon (i.e., "group:name"). You have no control over the values of the group, name, or module. It depends entirely on what the library is published under.

You do have control over how an entry is referenced in a build script, as that depends on the left-hand side ("androidx-core-ktx" and "androidx-lifecycle-viewmodel-compose" in your example). Think of it like a variable that you assign a dependency to. You can name this variable whatever you want (well, not whatever; it has to be a legal identifier). However, you'll want to name the variable something that identifies the library for readability. As for naming conventions for the "variable", this blog post may be helpful: https://blog.gradle.org/best-practices-naming-version-catalog-entries
